Description: Short bronze blade of a battle-axe: with thick elongated lugs and relatively short squat blade with splayed sides. The butt is markedly expanded at the centre and has pronounced flanges on each edge. The blade has been completely cleaned. There is considerable corrosion damage to the butt and the cutting edge, and there is superficial pitting on both faces. The blade is further disfigured by a large number of scratches and shallow tool-marks.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Tell el-Yahudiya (said to be from)
Curator's comments: Bibliography: E. A. W. Budge in 'Archaeologica: or Miscellaneous Tracts relating to Antiquity' 53 (London, 1892), 92; E. Kühnert-Eggesbrecht, ‘Die Axt als Waffe und Werkzeug im alten Ägypten’ (Berlin, 1969), 112, G-X/7.
Bibliographic references: Davies 1987 / Catalogue of Egyptian Antiquities in the British Museum (131)
Exhibition history: Exhibited: 1998/9 Oct-Jun, South Carolina, The Charleston Museum, Queens Commoners of the New Kingdom
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Rev Greville John Chester
